summary: This is an email chain from April 3, 2020, between attorney Sarah Coyne and an unidentified recipient, likely a federal prosecutor. Coyne discusses her intent to file a sealed motion for a sentence reduction for an unnamed female client ('her') who attempted to cooperate with the SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. The email seeks the recipient's review and potential agreement regarding the characterization of the client's cooperation.

persons.name: Sarah Coyne
persons.context: Attorney communicating her intent to file a sealed motion for a sentence reduction for an unnamed female client who attempted to cooperate with the SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of an SDNY investigation into the events surrounding his death, with which the unnamed client attempted to cooperate.

connections.description: Sarah Coyne is the attorney preparing a sentence reduction motion for her unnamed female client.
The unnamed client attempted to cooperate with the SDNY investigation into the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death, indicating a potential connection to the case.

events.title: Attorney Plans Sentence Reduction Motion
events.description: Attorney Sarah Coyne emails an unidentified recipient (likely a prosecutor) stating she will file a sealed motion on Tuesday to have her client's sentence reduced, citing the client's attempted cooperation with the SDNY Epstein death investigation.

keyFacts: An unnamed female individual, represented by attorney Sarah Coyne, attempted to cooperate with the Southern District of New York (SDNY) investigation into the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.
Attorney Sarah Coyne planned to file a sealed motion for a sentence reduction for this client on or after April 7, 2020 (the Tuesday following the April 3 email).
Coyne had already discussed the motion with an EDNY Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) and provided a draft, hoping for the AUSA's support.

The email seeks the recipient's (likely a prosecutor's) review of the motion portion detailing the client's assistance to ensure accurate characterization and to potentially agree to advise the court of the cooperation attempt.
The document highlights post-Epstein death legal maneuvers where associates sought sentence reductions based on cooperation with the ongoing investigation.
